com.vuzix.sdk.speechrecognitionservice

Class VuzixSpeechClient

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.vuzix.sdk.speechrecognitionservice.VuzixSpeechClient

  • public class VuzixSpeechClient
extends java.lang.Object

    Vuzix Speech Recognition Custom Vocabulary Guide

    Introduction

    The Vuzix Speech Recognizer is a fully embedded, fast, phrase-matching recognition system designed to interpret and respond to voice commands. A platform base vocabulary is available to all apps; it is intended to facilitate default navigation and selection without direction from the client app. That is, a client app can benefit from navigation provided by a base vocabulary with no setup or explicit awareness of the speech recognizer. This capability is implemented by mapping phrases to Android key events (android.view.KeyEvent, as described in https://developer.android.com/reference/android/view/KeyEvent.html

    For many applications, it is desirable to implement a custom vocabulary which performs application-specific actions when an application-specific phrase is spoken (e.g. to capture a still image when “take a picture” is spoken.) The Vuzix Speech Recognition system provides two mechanisms by which this can be achieved: Android key events as previously described and Android intents.

    Custom vocabulary architecture

    The Vuzix Speech Recognizer is implemented as a bound Android service running both Java and native code. The service is notified of context switches in Android when an activity or fragment is resumed (onResume() called.) In response, the recognizer checks for a custom vocabulary associated with the resumed activity or fragment. If found, the recognizer switches to this vocabulary. If not found, and if the resumed object is a fragment, the recognizer does not switch vocabulary. (This allows a resumed fragment to use the vocabulary of its already-resumed parent activity.)

    An activity using a custom vocabulary interacts with the Vuzix Speech Recognition service through an Android content provider, which models a vocabulary as a database supporting query, insert, delete, and update operations. A phrase is modeled as a “database entry”, that is, vocabulary objects are keyed on the text representation of the spoken phrase.

    Custom vocabulary usage

    A custom vocabulary for an activity should be specified in its onCreate() method using a constructor like:
    VuzixSpeechClient sc = new VuzixSpeechClient(this);

    Base vocabulary inheritance

    The custom vocabulary is created when the VuzixSpeechClient class is instantiated. The newly instantiated custom vocabulary inherits the platform base vocabulary, which is currently:
    • KEYCODE_DPAD_LEFT : "move left"
    • KEYCODE_DPAD_RIGHT : "move right"
    • KEYCODE_DPAD_UP : "move up"
    • KEYCODE_DPAD_DOWN : "move down"
    • KEYCODE_NAVIGATE_IN : "move in"
    • KEYCODE_NAVIGATE_OUT : "move out"
    • KEYCODE_FORWARD : "move forward"
    • KEYCODE_BACK : "move back"
    • KEYCODE_DPAD_LEFT : "scroll left"
    • KEYCODE_DPAD_RIGHT : "scroll right"
    • KEYCODE_DPAD_UP : "scroll up"
    • KEYCODE_DPAD_DOWN : "scroll down"
    • KEYCODE_DPAD_LEFT : "go left"
    • KEYCODE_DPAD_RIGHT : "go right"
    • KEYCODE_DPAD_UP : "go up"
    • KEYCODE_DPAD_DOWN : "go down"
    • KEYCODE_NAVIGATE_IN : "go in"
    • KEYCODE_NAVIGATE_OUT : "go out"
    • KEYCODE_FORWARD : "go forward"
    • KEYCODE_BACK : "go back"
    • KEYCODE_HOME : "go home"
    • KEYCODE_HOME : "go home"
    • KEYCODE_ENTER : "select this"
    • KEYCODE_ENTER : "pick this"
    • KEYCODE_HOME : "quit"
    • KEYCODE_ENTER : "okay"
    • KEYCODE_ENTER : "confirm"
    • KEYCODE_NAVIGATE_NEXT : "next"
    • KEYCODE_NAVIGATE_PREVIOUS : "previous"
    • KEYCODE_ESCAPE : "cancel"
    • KEYCODE_MENU : "show menu"
    • "stop"
    • "torch on"
    • "flashlight on"
    • "light on"
    • "torch off"
    • "flashlight off"
    • "light off"
    • "go to sleep"
    • "hello vuzix"
    • "voice off"
    • "please exit evaluation mode"
    • "please enter evaluation mode"

    For each of the above phrases preceded by a "KEYCODE_..." value, that keycode is generated when the phrase is spoken. Each of the phrases without a keycode results in an intent broadcast to effect its action.

    Getting Started

    New users should start with the simplest command: insertPhrase(String phrase)
    Since:
    SDK version 2, M300 version 1.2.2 (20170915)
    See Also:
    insertPhrase(String phrase)

    • Field Detail

      • ACTION_VOICE_COMMAND

        public static final java.lang.String ACTION_VOICE_COMMAND

        String that is registered for Intents coming from the Speech Client. Your Activity must have a BroadcastReceiver class that can use this string for the Intent Filter. 

         For example, from a BroadcastHandler helper class:

     iActivity.registerReceiver(this, new IntentFilter(VuzixSpeechClient.ACTION_VOICE_COMMAND));

 or from an Activity containing a BroadcastHandlerHelper:

     this.registerReceiver(mMyBroadcastHandlerClass, new IntentFilter(VuzixSpeechClient.ACTION_VOICE_COMMAND));
        Since:
        SDK version 2, M300 version 1.2.2 (20170915)
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • PHRASE_STRING_EXTRA

        public static final java.lang.String PHRASE_STRING_EXTRA

        Broadcast receivers will get an intent with action ACTION_VOICE_COMMAND and string extra PHRASE_STRING_EXTRA whenever a custom phrase they have inserted is heard.

        Since:
        SDK version 2, M300 version 1.2.2 (20170915)
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • RECOGNIZER_ACTIVE_BOOL_EXTRA

        public static final java.lang.String RECOGNIZER_ACTIVE_BOOL_EXTRA

        Broadcast receivers will get an intent with action ACTION_VOICE_COMMAND and boolean extra RECOGNIZER_ACTIVE_BOOL_EXTRA whenever the recognizer is triggered (ie: "Hello Vuzix"), or times-out.

        When the recognizer begins to listen, the boolean is set true. When the recognizer ceases to listen, the boolean is set false

        Since:
        SDK version 4, M300 version 1.2.6 (20180403)
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • dump

        public java.lang.String dump()
        Dumps the content of the entire speech recognition phrase map. This is used for debugging. It includes inherited entries and custom entries.
        Returns:
        String with a single phrase pair per row, separated by carriage returns
        Since:
        SDK version 2, M300 version 1.2.2 (20170915)

      • insertPhrase

        public boolean insertPhrase(java.lang.String phrase)

        This is the most basic way to insert a phrase into the recognizer.

         For Example:
    sc.insertPhrase("take photo"));

        The phrase will be provided unchanged (note: spaces are replaced by underscores) in a "phrase" string extra in the intent as demonstrated below:

            @Override
     public void onReceive(Context context, Intent intent) {
         if (intent.getAction().equals(VuzixSpeechClient.ACTION_VOICE_COMMAND)) {
             String phrase = intent.getStringExtra("phrase");
             if (phrase != null && phrase.equals("take_photo")) {
                 // Do something
             }
         }
     }

        This method is useful fur developers learning to use the Speech Client. For commercialized apps, it is recommended that the optional substitution is provided using the method insertPhrase(String phrase, String substitution) instead of this method

        Parameters:
        phrase - String for which the Speech recognizer will listen
        Returns:
        True if the phrase is added. False otherwise.
        Since:
        SDK version 2, M300 version 1.2.2 (20170915)
        See Also:
        insertPhrase(String phrase, String substitution)

      • insertPhrase

        public boolean insertPhrase(java.lang.String phrase,
                   java.lang.String substitution)

        Similar to insertPhrase(String phrase)

        This inserts a phrase to recognize and defines a substitution. The substitution will be returned when the phrase is recognized. This is useful when dealing with localize recognition phrases. Regardless of the active langauge, the substitution string will always be identified to your code

         For Example, instead of:
    sc.insertPhrase("take photo"));
 use:
    sc.insertPhrase(mContext.getString(R.string.voice_cmd_take_photo), "take_photo");

        Regardless of the active language, your code will always receive "take_photo". So your code does not need to be modified for localization. Just as with text localization, the strings.xml resource will have:

             English: <string name="voice_cmd_take_photo">take photo</string>
     French:  <string name="voice_cmd_take_photo">prendre une photo</string>
     German:  <string name="voice_cmd_take_photo">machen Sie ein Foto</string>
     Spanish: <string name="voice_cmd_take_photo">toma una foto</string>
     Chinese: <string name="voice_cmd_take_photo">拍照</string>
     etc.

        The recognized phrase will be correctly selected based on localization (note that the recognizer itself must have the correct language recognition files loaded.)

        Parameters:
        phrase - String for which the Speech recognizer will listen. This should likely be a localized string from a resource file.
        substitution - String that will be returned upon detecting the phrase. This should be a constant, regardless of the active language.
        Returns:
        True if the phrase is added. False otherwise.
        Since:
        SDK version 2, M300 version 1.2.2 (20170915)
        See Also:
        insertPhrase(String phrase)

      • insertKeycodePhrase

        public boolean insertKeycodePhrase(java.lang.String phrase,
                          int keyevent,
                          int repeatIntervalMs,
                          java.lang.String params)

        Similar to insertKeycodePhrase(String phrase, int keyevent). This adds optional repeat interval and optional internal speech recognizer parameters

        Parameters:
        phrase - String for which the Speech recognizer will listen. This should likely be a localized string from a resource file.
        keyevent - The eventcode as defined in android.view.KeyEvent
        repeatIntervalMs - int interval at which the keycode event will be generated
        params - String parameters (undocumented)
        Returns:
        True if the phrase is added. False otherwise.
        Since:
        SDK version 2, M300 version 1.2.2 (20170915)
        See Also:
        insertKeycodePhrase(String phrase, int keyevent), insertKeycodePhrase(String phrase, int keyevent, String params), insertKeycodePhrase(String phrase, int keyevent, int repeatIntervalMs)

        public boolean insertKeycodePhrase(java.lang.String phrase,
                          int keyevent,
                          int repeatIntervalMs)

        Similar to insertKeycodePhrase(String phrase, int keyevent)

        This repeats the key at the specified interval until a new phrase (e.g. "stop") is recognized

        Parameters:
        phrase - String for which the Speech recognizer will listen. This should likely be a localized string from a resource file.
        keyevent - The eventcode as defined in android.view.KeyEvent

      • insertKeycodePhrase

        public boolean insertKeycodePhrase(java.lang.String phrase,
                          int keyevent)

        The most basic way to insert a phrase to generate a keycode.

        Upon recognition of a phrase, the recognizer may be configured to generate an Android key event, just as if a key had been pressed on a physical keypad.

         Example:
      sc.insertKeycodePhrase("zero", KeyEvent.KEYCODE_0);
 or better:
      sc.insertKeycodePhrase(mContext.getString(R.string.voice_cmd_zero), KeyEvent.KEYCODE_0);
        Parameters:
        phrase - String for which the Speech recognizer will listen. This should likely be a localized string from a resource file.
        keyevent - The eventcode as defined in android.view.KeyEvent
        Returns:
        True if the phrase is added. False otherwise.
        Since:
        SDK version 2, M300 version 1.2.2 (20170915)

      • insertIntentPhrase

        public boolean insertIntentPhrase(java.lang.String phrase,
                         java.lang.String intentLabel,
                         java.lang.String params)
                           throws android.os.RemoteException

        Similar to insertIntentPhrase(String phrase, String intentLabel(). This adds optionnal inernal speech client parameters

        Parameters:
        phrase - String for which the Speech recognizer will listen. This should likely be a localized string from a resource file.
        intentLabel - String label matching one previously registered using defineIntent()
        params - String parameters (undocumented)
        Returns:
        True if the phrase is added. False otherwise.
        Throws:

        See Also:

      • insertIntentPhrase

        public boolean insertIntentPhrase(java.lang.String phrase,
                         java.lang.String intentLabel)
                           throws android.os.RemoteException

        If the preformed intent is not sufficient for the app use case, an arbitrarily defined intent may be used. In this case, the intent must be defined for the vocabulary as well as be registered in the app's intent filter and parsed in the app's intent receiver.

        A free-form intent may have an arbitrarily specified Action, Data, Type, and Component, and may contain extras. The extras are limited to Boolean, Integer, and String types. Probably the most useful free-form intent case is use of a custom Action; this will target the broadcast intent from the recognizer to this application.

        The Intent to be broadcast must be specified to the vocabulary using defineIntent() before it can be used here

        Note: Intents are sent with sendBroadcastAsUser() from the service. They will not start new activities as would happen from startActivityForResult()

         Note that the same intent (as identified by this label) may be associated with many phrases:
     sc.insertIntentPhrase("focus image", “cam_focus”);
        sc.insertIntentPhrase("do focus", “cam_focus”); sc.insertIntentPhrase("sharpen image", “cam_focus”);

        (While these examples use fixed strings for the sake of clarity, the use of string resources to facilitate localization, as described above, is highly recommended.)

        Parameters:
        phrase - String for which the Speech recognizer will listen. This should likely be a localized string from a resource file.
        intentLabel - String label matching one previously registered using defineIntent()
        Returns:
        True if the phrase is added. False otherwise.
        Throws:
        android.os.RemoteException
        Since:
        SDK version 2, M300 version 1.2.2 (20170915)
        See Also:
        defineIntent(String, Intent)

      • insertWakeWordPhrase

        public boolean insertWakeWordPhrase(java.lang.String phrase)

        Insert a phrase to activate the recognizer, like "hello vuzix" from the base vocabulary. If a developer calls deleteAll() this will also delete the default wake word, meaning speech recognition cannot be reactivated without another wake word being added. This function allows for developers to use custom wake words if they prefer.

        Parameters:
        phrase - String for which the Speech recognizer will listen. This should likely be a localized string from a resource file.
        Since:
        SDK version 5, Not applicable to M300, Blade version 2.6

      • insertVoiceOffPhrase

        public boolean insertVoiceOffPhrase(java.lang.String phrase)

        Insert a phrase to deactivate the recognizer, like "voice off" from the base vocabulary.

        Parameters:
        phrase - String for which the Speech recognizer will listen. This should likely be a localized string from a resource file.
        Since:
        SDK version 5, M300 version 1.6.6, Blade version 2.6
        See Also:
        insertWakeWordPhrase(String)

      • deletePhrase

        public boolean deletePhrase(java.lang.String phrase)

        A phrase may be deleted from the list inherited from the base vocabulary (or a custom phrase may be later deleted) using this method

        Note that the deletion is in effect only when this activity is running; the base vocabulary which is used outside the context of this activity is not affected.

         For Example:
     sc.deletePhrase("take photo");
 or better:
     sc.deletePhrase( mContext.getString(R.string.voice_cmd_take_photo) );

        To delete all phrases, use the string "*"

        Parameters:
        phrase - String to be deleted from the speech recognition map
        Returns:
        true if the phrase is found and deleted. false if the string is not present in the map.
        Since:
        SDK version 2, M300 version 1.2.2 (20170915)

      • defineIntent

        public boolean defineIntent(java.lang.String label,
                   android.content.Intent intent)
                     throws android.os.RemoteException

        This method defines an arbitrary Intent that may be associated with phrases.

        Note: Intents are sent with sendBroadcastAsUser() from the service. They will not start new activities as would happen from startActivityForResult()

        This method must be called prior to calling insertIntentPhrase()

         For example:
     Intent focus_intent = new Intent(“com.mycompany.camera.speechrecog”).putExtra("focus", true);
     sc.defineIntent("cam_focus", focus_intent);
     sc.insertIntentPhrase("focus image", “cam_focus”);

        Here, defineIntent() defines the intent for the vocabulary's later use, assigning it a label (“cam_focus”) by which it will be identified in insertIntentPhrase()

        Parameters:
        label - String by which this new Intent will be identified during insertIntentPhrase()
        intent - Intent your Activity wishes to recieve
        Returns:
        true if the Intent can be defined. false otherwise.
        Throws:
        android.os.RemoteException
        Since:
        SDK version 2, M300 version 1.2.2 (20170915)
        See Also:
        insertIntentPhrase(String, String)

      • storeVocabulary

        public boolean storeVocabulary(java.lang.String name)

        Save a recognizer vocabulary in the vocabulary store for later use.

        At launch, an application inherits the base speech recognition vocabulary. It will typically modify this vocabulary, adding and deleting phrases to create a vocabulary suited to its use. For a static activity or fragment, this is all that is needed, but some activities may dynamically modify the content affected by speech commands, and hence need to modify the vocabulary.

        The {store, retrieve, remove} mechanism allows vocabulary "snapshots" to be saved and later retrieved. For example, the base vocabulary may be replaced with a vocabulary which supports basic navigation, selection, and processing. This "activity base" vocabulary is then saved, and to it is added the names of several icons being displayed. On "next page", this set of icons is replaced by a new set of icons. The activity retrieves the saved "activity base" vocabulary (which will not contain the names of the previous set of icons) and adds the names of the new set of icons being displayed.

         Example:
      sc.storeVocabulary("SortActivityBase");
        Parameters:
        name - String (arbitrary) representing an activity-unique label for this vocabulary snapshot.
        Returns:
        True if the vocabulary is stored. False otherwise.
        Since:
        SDK version 4, M300 version 1.2.6 (20180403)

      • removeVocabulary

        public boolean removeVocabulary(java.lang.String name)

        Remove and delete the recognizer vocabulary in the vocabulary store represented by "name".

        Parameters:
        name - String (arbitrary) representing an activity-unique label for the vocabulary snapshot.
        Returns:
        True if the vocabulary is deleted. False otherwise.
        Since:
        SDK version 4, M300 version 1.2.6 (20180403)

      • retrieveVocabulary

        public boolean retrieveVocabulary(java.lang.String name)

        Replace the current activity vocabulary with the vocabulary from the vocabulary store represented by "name".

        This method replaces the current vocabulary for an activity with the saved snapshot of the activity's vocabulary in the vocabulary store represented by "name".

        Parameters:
        name - String (arbitrary) representing an activity-unique label for the vocabulary snapshot.
        Returns:
        True if the vocabulary replacement is successful. False otherwise.
        Since:
        SDK version 4, M300 version 1.2.6 (20180403)

      • control

        public boolean control(java.lang.String type,
              java.lang.String params)

        This method invokes a control method with selector "type" and parameters "params."

        An example (currently implemented): 

            control("trigger", null);
        will trigger the recognizer programmatically (equivalent to TriggerVoiceAudio())

        Since:
        SDK version 4, M300 version 1.2.6 (20180403)

        Since:

      • TriggerVoiceAudio

        public static void TriggerVoiceAudio(boolean triggered)

        This method externally triggers or deactivates the Speech Recognition engine programmatically. It is the equivalent of recognizing the trigger phrase (e.g. "Hello Vuzix" in an audio stream.

        Note: Use the method with the Context parameter if possible; the no-parameter method is less reliable.

        Parameters:
        triggered - True to trigger the recognizer; False to put it to sleep it.
        Since:
        SDK version 4, M300 version 1.2.6 (20180403)
        See Also:
        TriggerVoiceAudio(Context)

      • TriggerVoiceAudio

        public static void TriggerVoiceAudio()

        This method externally triggers the Speech Recognition engine programmatically. It is the equivalent of the above method with the "triggered" parameter set to true.

        Note: Use the method with the Context parameter if possible; the no-parameter method is less reliable.

        Since:
        SDK version 3, M300 version 1.2.5 (20180202)
        See Also:
        TriggerVoiceAudio(boolean)

      • TriggerVoiceAudio

        public static void TriggerVoiceAudio(android.content.Context context,
                     boolean triggered)

        This method externally triggers or deactivates the Speech Recognition engine programmatically. It is the equivalent of recognizing the trigger phrase (e.g. "Hello Vuzix" in an audio stream.

        Note: This is the preferred method invocation, explicitly specifying a valid Context.

        Parameters:
        context - The context from which the trigger is being invoked
        triggered - True to trigger the recognizer; False to put it to sleep it.
        Since:
        SDK version 4, M300 version 1.2.6 (20180403)

      • TriggerVoiceAudio

        public static void TriggerVoiceAudio(android.content.Context context)

        This method externally triggers the Speech Recognition engine programmatically. It is the equivalent of the above method with the "triggered" parameter set to true.

        Parameters:
        context - The context from which the trigger is being invoked
        Since:
        SDK version 3, M300 version 1.2.5 (20180202)
        See Also:
        TriggerVoiceAudio(Context, boolean)

      • EnableRecognizer

        public static void EnableRecognizer(boolean enabled)

        This method enables or disables the Speech Recognition engine programmatically. It is the equivalent of turning on or off the "Enable Vuzix Speech Recognition" switch in the global Settings application.

        Use the method with the Context parameter if possible; the no-parameter method is less reliable.

        Parameters:
        enabled - True to enable the recognizer; False to disable it.
        Since:
        SDK version 3, M300 version 1.2.5 (20180202)

      • EnableRecognizer

        public static void EnableRecognizer(android.content.Context context,
                    boolean enabled)

        This method enables or disables the Speech Recognition engine programmatically. It is the equivalent of turning on or off the "Enable Vuzix Speech Recognition" switch in the global Settings application.

        Note: This is the preferred method invocation, explicitly specifying a valid Context.

        Parameters:
        context - The context from which the trigger is being invoked
        enabled - True to enable voice recognition, False to disable
        Since:
        SDK version 3, M300 version 1.2.5 (20180202)
